channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Russia Sentences a U.S. Citizen, Eugene Spector, to 15 Years for Espionage
item.description: Eugene Spector was already serving a sentence for a bribery conviction when he was charged with spying, for which a court ordered him to serve an addi...

item.title: Dutch Court Issues Prison Sentences Over Violence Against Israeli Soccer Fans
item.description: Five people were found guilty of crimes, including public violence, in relation to attacks targeting Israelis in Amsterdam last month.

item.title: Russia Sentences a U.S. Citizen, Eugene Spector, to 15 Years for Espionage
item.description: Eugene Spector was already serving a sentence for a bribery conviction when he was charged with spying, for which a court ordered him to serve an addi...

item.title: Scientist says the one thing everyone hates about AI is ultimately what helped him win a Nobel Prize
item.description: In October, David Baker was the only American scientist to win the Nobel Prize in Chemistry.

item.title: As Rome Prepares for a Tourist Surge, Residents Fear Losing the City’s Soul
item.description: The Catholic Jubilee in 2025 is expected to draw 32 million visitors. Officials are proud of the city’s accompanying makeover, but residents lament so...

item.title: Blake Lively Turns the Shame Around
item.description: The actress’s lawsuit may prolong a humiliating episode for her. But the only way to end impunity is to speak up.

item.title: La-Z-Boy launches ‘never recline’ petition for airplane passenger seats—and it’s closing in on 200,000 signatures
item.description: Petition signers can win a free recliner and $500 toward a flight.

item.title: As Rome Prepares for a Tourist Surge, Residents Fear Losing the City’s Soul
item.description: The Catholic Jubilee in 2025 is expected to draw 32 million visitors. Officials are proud of the city’s accompanying makeover, but residents lament so...

item.title: American Airlines Briefly Grounds U.S. Flights on Christmas Eve Over Technical Issue
item.description: Flights were grounded for about an hour on Christmas Eve, one of the busiest travel days of the year, before the airline restored its systems. But hea...

item.title: A Canceled Vote in Romania Hands Russia a Propaganda Coup
item.description: Many in the West have applauded the annulling of the first round of the presidential election, won by a Moscow-friendly candidate, but even his critic...

item.title: Syria's Tangled Alliances and Rivalries: A Visual Guide
item.description: After the fall of President Bashar al-Assad, old alliances have crumbled, and global powers are figuring out their relationships with Syria’s new de f...

item.title: Biden will decide whether US Steel can be sold to a Japanese company for $15 billion
item.description: Some federal agencies were skeptical that allowing a Japanese company to buy an American steelmaker would create national security risks.

item.title: More Starbucks Store Workers Will Join Strike for Final Day
item.description: The strike began Friday at stores in the Los Angeles, Seattle and Chicago areas and will end on Tuesday.

item.title: The Fed is weighing ‘significant changes’ to its annual stress tests for large U.S. banks to lessen the risk of large year-on-year swings
item.description: The stress test has helped banks more than double their capital levels over the past decade-plus.

item.title: Millennials and Gen X will inherit $83.5 trillion in the next two decades—but not before spouses of the wealthy obtain their $9 trillion
